Nadav Lapid, a voice of dissension in Israeli cinema
subhead: Celebrated at international festivals, Nadav Lapid's films have provoked controversy in his home country. His latest work, the acerbic 'Yes,' explores the aftermath of October 7 and sharply criticizes a society consumed by vengeance and nationalism.

title: Strikes in France on September 18: What to expect
subhead: For the first time since 2023, labor unions have called for protests across all sectors, from schools to transport, in opposition to austerity measures in the 2026 budget plan which the new prime minister has not ruled out.
byline: By Aline Leclerc, Guy Dutheil, Pierre Manière, Jonathan Parienté, Adrien Pécout, Jules Thomas, Eléa Pommiers, Zeliha Chaffin and Brice Laemle

title: Kvaratskhelia stunner helps holders PSG to winning Champions League start
subhead: Paris Saint-Germain, which won 4-0 against Atalanta on Wednesday, hardly had any off-season break after the last campaign, which stretched over 65 games and 11 months. The French Club's victory comes after losing star forwards Ousmane Dembélé and Désiré Doué for several weeks to injuries.

title: El Salvador: From 'Surf City' beaches to overflowing prisons – the two sides of the Bukele model
subhead: President Nayib Bukele has propelled El Salvador to the top of the world ranking for incarceration rate, with nearly 1.7% of the population behind bars. At the same time, the Central American state has welcomed 3.5 million tourists, far outpacing Costa Rica.

title: Who is Gabriel Zucman, billionaires' nightmare?
subhead: Since Sébastien Lecornu's appointment as prime minister, Gabriel Zucman's name has been everywhere in French media. The economist's proposal for a 2% wealth tax on the ultra-rich has returned to the forefront of public debate.

subhead: Marine Le Pen and Jordan Bardella's statements about whether they would seek to govern after new snap elections raise questions about their true willingness to wield power before the 2027 presidential election.

title: The Paris district where Parisians are priced out
subhead: In 50 years, the 8th arrondissement of the French capital, home to the Champs-Elysées and the 'Golden Triangle,' has lost nearly half its population. The mass acquisition of real estate by ultra-wealthy foreigners has driven locals out.
byline: By Véronique Chocron and Manon Romain

title: French border police accused of causing shipwrecks and deaths of migrants from Comoros
subhead: Since 2010, several hundred Comorians have died at sea while trying to reach the French overseas territory of Mayotte. A joint investigation by Le Monde and Lighthouse Reports shows that police maneuvers are implicated in several of these shipwrecks.
byline: By Raphaëlle Aubert, Julia Pascual (Mayotte), Jack Sapoch (motion design, Lighthouse Reports), Tomas Statius (Mayotte, Lighthouse Reports) and Maud Jullien (Lighthouse Reports)
